awd_abstract_narration:
With the continuing proliferation of wireless technology, a wide spectrum of emerging applications using this technology will be tightly interwoven into the fabric of our everyday lives: wireless sensor networks can monitor personal health or critical infrastructures. The viability and success of many of these applications critically hinges on the availability of the underlying wireless communication. As wireless networks become increasingly pervasive, the problem of radio interference and jamming will be inevitable, raising a serious threat to the availability of wireless services.  To enable the continuous and highly-available data delivery services over the entire lifetime of wireless networks in support of wireless applications, it is crucial that the wireless networks have built-in strong defense mechanisms against interference and jamming.
 
This project aims to develop a suite of holistic solutions that monitor the radio environment and provide quick recovery to interrupted services in case of jamming or radio interference. In contrast to traditional techniques, such as spread spectrum which requires costly new hardware, the proposed techniques involve networks to manage their resources collaboratively across all layers to assure the availability of network services, leveraging existing commodity wireless platforms. Through the interaction with industry partners, the project results are expected to provide guidance for coping with jamming in future network architecture. 
 The educational component of this project seeks to prepare students to face the challenges of rapidly evolving technologies in wireless networks. The experimental and design components of this project will enhance both the undergraduate and graduate students? education in related areas.

por.por_cntn:
Jamming/Radio interference is a serious threat to the availability of wireless services. It has been traditionally addressed at the physical layer through signal modulation approaches, such as spread spectrum, and has been examined recently at the MAC layer. These single layer solutions primarily focus on the micro level, e.g., single nodes. To accomplish the missions of wireless networks, in this project we have conducted the following tasks. (1) Instead of using traditional sophisticated PHY layer solutions that require costly new hardware, we used existing commodity wireless platforms. We have designed multiple algorithms to localize jammers and have validated our algorithms on both MicaZ platform and simulation over large-scale networks. We also managed to detect and localize a mobile GPS jammer using low cost solutions. In addition, we investigated intentional Electromagnetic interference injection attacks against analog sensors, and showed that it is possible to alter what microphones can record and what an implantable pacemaker can sense, wirelessly, via interference only. (2) Instead of focusing on protecting each individual node from radio interference in either the PHY or MAC layer, networks should manage their resources collaboratively across all layers to assure the availability of network services in the presence of jamming/radio interference. As such, we designed multi-path routing protocols that enable the protection of highly available wireless services against jamming and radio interference.

 

 

 

Wireless networks are attaining critical importance for public transportation safety, national security, individual health surveillance, etc. Most of these applications are not deployable without anti-jamming protection, as jammers can easily disturb their function.  What we have found in this project provides insights to enhance legacy devices, and the work can serve as guidance in building jamming resistant wireless networks. The educational component of the project has prepared students to face the challenges of rapidly evolving technologies in wireless networks. The experimental and design components of this project has enhanced both the undergraduate and graduate education at University of South Carolina, an EPSCoR state with an insufficient workforce in wireless network security and a large minority population that is underrepresented in science and engineering.
